Award.AwardTitle: LTREB: TESTING FOR FACULTATIVE SWITCHING BETWEEN MIGRATORY STRATEGIES IN A PARTIALLY MIGRATORY, LONG-LIVED LARGE HERBIVORE POPULATION
Award.AbstractNarration:
Animal migrations figure among the most spectacular natural phenomena, ranging from Monarch butterflies that migrate up to 3,000 miles to over-winter in warm climates to Arctic terns that travel each year between the Arctic and the Antarctic. Migratory species are declining worldwide due to human disturbance, habitat loss, and climate change. In the presence of these ongoing changes, the ecology of migration has become an important management issue. This research extends a 15-year study of elk to understand why, across migratory species, there are individuals that migrate and those that do not migrate within a single population. The project will help understand the causes of migratory decision-making among elk and the implications of altered migratory behavior for elk conservation and management. The researchers will engage graduate students in journalism, who will develop diverse media outlets to communicate results broadly, and in geography, who will develop web interfaces for the public to view elk migration virtually. The project will offer internships to Native American students through the Native American Natural Resource Program at the University of Montana. General fascination with migratory animals along with the broad appeal of elk to conservationists, hunters, and Native Americans alike promise effective citizen outreach and engagement.

The researchers will use a partly-migratory population of elk as a model system to understand the context-dependent costs and benefits of partial migration. The project builds on long-term knowledge of the demography of more than 300 individually marked female elk of known age, individual reproductive rates, and juvenile survival rates, combined with spatial analyses of migratory behavior measured by Global Positioning System (GPS) collars. The researchers will monitor both intrinsic factors such as age and reproductive history and extrinsic factors such as forage and predation risk to test competing and interacting hypotheses to understand why a long-lived mammal switches between migratory strategies in the face of environmental change. They will next incorporate results on the causes of switching into a population model that explicitly tests for the effects of switching on population dynamics. A Bayesian state-space population model, Bayesian model selection, and cross-validation of competing models with and without different switching functions will test between two alternate hypotheses for the population dynamic effects of partial migration as well as the relative importance of bottom-up (forage) versus top-down (predation) forces on population growth rates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Migratory species are crucial to ecosystems because they can attain higher abundance by migrating, and thus often drive ecological processes like predation and herbivory.  Yet migratory species are also declining because of human disturbance, habitat loss, and climate change.  In particular, ungulates like deer and elk are both ecologically and economically important (e.g., hunting), and yet their migrations are in decline.  Understanding the causes of declines is key for their conservation and management.  However, across species, there are usually individuals who migrate and others who do not migrate within a single population.  Our previous research showed, for the first time in elk, that individuals can decide whether and where to migrate. Our goals were first to understand the causes of migratory decision making in elk, and second, the population consequences of changes in migratory behavior. This research has broad implications for management for species such as deer and elk across western North America.

 This research harnesses the power of a 20-year, long-term study of migratory elk in a typical western North American montane landscape to address these 2 questions.  The core data for this research is understanding the demography of >300 individually marked female elk of known age, their reproductive rates, and juvenile survival, combined with spatial analyses of their migratory behavior from Global Positioning System (GPS) collars. Our first research question was testing whether individual elk switch between migratory tactics from year to year because of intrinsic (e.g., age, body condition), environmental (wolf or grizzly bear predation risk, climate), or density-dependent (e.g., to avoid overcrowding) factors. Our second question was whether behavioral decisions made by individual elk had population consequences on the dynamics of this partially migratory population.

We addressed our two main research questions by developing a flexible population model. We used 20 years of demographic and behavioral data from > 300 adult female elk, their calves, and long-term data on forage quality and predator predation risk. We found density dependence only for resident pregnancy and adult female survival. This indicated that early in our study in 2000, higher elk densities on the shared winter range negatively affected residents more than migrants. This explained our why resident elk were more likely to switch to migratory tactics at these higher densities to avoid overcrowding.  Since 2015, however, as elk densities declined, we found evidence of migrants switching back to a residency tactic to enhance calf survival. Thus, our results indicate individual elk make decisions to migrate or not based on maximizing survival of their calves.  

Despite differences in demographic rates (e.g., juvenile survival) between migratory tactics, average population growth rate of each migratory tactic was equal.  This was because individuals switched tactics from year to year, seeking out the best tactic based on adult and juvenile survival the previous year. But so did every individual elk, resulting in everyone experiencing the same average success. In our system, because adult female survival rates were so similar, the search for the 'ideal' migratory tactic for migratory elk seems driven mostly by reproduction and the 'safest' place to successfully raise a calf to 1 year of age.  Our results show migration is maintained by conditional decisions to migrate that stabilizes the long-term abundance of a population.  Loss of migrants, for example, would lead to lower population size and greater population instability. Our research has broad implications for the management of ungulates and their migration across the US and globe, and more broadly across migratory species from songbirds to salmon. Building on our research, we participated in launching the Global Initiative on Ungulate Migration in partnership with the Wyoming Migration Initiative, IUCN and Convention on Migratory Species.

In the 5-years of NSF funding, our research trained > 100 undergraduate students and research technicians, 3 undergraduate theses, 6 Masters theses, and 2 PhD students.  Our graduate students now work across the western United States and Canada managing wildlife in positions with State and Federal natural resource agencies, Universities, and private industry. Our research directly contributed to enhanced natural resource management such as prescribed fire management, hunting harvest management, endangered species management, and National park management. Our research generated at least 36 peer reviewed scientific papers in premier scientific journals such as Science, Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, Ecology, and Journal of Wildlife Management.  We delivered broad scientific outreach through 42 presentations and conferences in 4 different countries and 7 different states and provinces, as well as online, within the reporting period. Our long-term datasets are publicly available on the open-access platform MOVEBANK and have been used in dozens of undergraduate and graduate classes and educational opportunities across the US and globe. Finally, we have a strong track record of delivering public presentations and getting our science covered in local, national, and global media, with >40 news stories in the last 5 years.
